properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Some freezing rain and freezing drizzle likely today. Precipitation associated with a low pressure system will affect portions of central Ontario today. Occasional freezing rain and freezing drizzle are likely, although amounts are not expected to be overly significant. The greatest likelihood is for areas closer to the Quebec border later today and tonight. A freezing rain warning may be required. Travel may be impacted as untreated surfaces may become slippery. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-27T08:24:00-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-26T16:25:00-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1593064549.2019

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowstorm potential Sunday and Monday. An intense low pressure system is expected to bring snow and blowing snow to areas near western Lake Superior Sunday and Monday. Very poor travel conditions are expected. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Some freezing rain and freezing drizzle likely tonight. Precipitation associated with an approaching low pressure system will move into eastern Ontario later today. Some freezing rain or freezing drizzle is likely tonight into Friday morning, although amounts are not expected to be overly significant. Areas closer to the Quebec border are most likely to experience the freezing rain, and warnings may be required as the event draws closer. Travel may be impacted from this evening until Friday morning as untreated surfaces may become slippery. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-27T08:32:28-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Major winter storm Sunday afternoon into Monday. A low from the southwestern United States will bring a winter storm to eastern and portions of central Ontario Sunday afternoon into Monday. Significant ice accumulation will be possible. The Ottawa Valley will be on the boundary of freezing rain and heavy snowfall. As a result, the amount of icing versus snowfall is currently uncertain in the Ottawa Valley with potential for a major snowfall instead. Travel is expected to rapidly deteriorate Sunday afternoon. Strong easterly winds are also forecast. Significant power outages are expected where the freezing rain is the primary mode of precipitation. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-27T12:21:27-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-26T20:22:27-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3108093212.2019

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds and a mix of rain and snow Friday night and Saturday. A sharp trough over the Pacific Ocean will approach Haida Gwaii Friday night then reach the mainland coast early Saturday. Strong southeasterly winds will rise as the system approaches, reaching up to 80 km/h on Haida Gwaii and on exposed coastal sections of the mainland. Moderate rain will be widespread, but mixed precipitation will occur over inland areas of the North Coast where warm, moist Pacific air will collide with the cooler air in place. Up to 10 cm of snow will fall at Terrace and up to 15 cm at Stewart before the change to rain Friday night. There is a risk of freezing rain during the transition from snow to rain. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-27T12:49:27-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-26T20:50:27-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0767421474.2019
Area: Haida Gwaii, Central Coast - coastal sections, North Coast - coastal sections, North Coast - inland including Terrace, North Coast - inland including Kitimat, North Coast - inland including Stewart
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Very large waves, pounding surf, and elevated sea water levels are expected Friday morning. Wave heights: 7 to 9 metres, breaking upon approach to shore. Locations: east and northeast coasts of Newfoundland. Time span: Friday morning. Remarks: A prolonged period of strong winds will cause very large waves to build today. Storm surge and coastal flooding may occur along shorelines exposed to the north and northeast, especially near high tide Friday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-27T15:31:13-00:00

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for today. Snow will affect portions of northwestern Ontario with up to 10 cm likely by later today. Some areas may see some freezing drizzle as well. Travel may become difficult. Visibility may be reduced at times in areas of heavier snow. Motorists are advised to exercise caution. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant mixed precipitation Sunday into Monday. An intense low pressure system is expected to bring a significant mix of wintry precipitation to much of northern Ontario Sunday into Monday, including snow, ice pellets and freezing rain. Some areas may see rain as well. Strong easterly winds will accompany the precipitation. Poor travel is expected, as well as potential for power outages in some areas. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-27T13:04:52-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Higher elevations of Metro Vancouver and portions of the Fraser Valley are likely to receive small accumulations of snow tonight. A front moving southward along the B.C. coast will meet a somewhat cool airmass in place over the lower mainland early this evening. Initially, precipitation will be a mix of snow and rain and 2 to 4 cm can be expected over higher terrain and in the Fraser Valley. Up to 5 cm is forecast for the eastern Fraser Valley. Precipitation will transition to rain near midnight over Metro Vancouver while the eastern Fraser Valley may remain as snow until Friday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-27T07:58:17-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-26T15:59:17-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2079299291.2019

properties.Title: Freezing Drizzle Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Areas of freezing drizzle are expected or occurring. Patchy freezing drizzle or light freezing rain is expected tonight across portions of northeastern Ontario and north of Lake Superior. Amounts should not be overly significant. However, locally slippery conditions are possible on untreated surfaces. Temperatures will slowly rise above the freezing mark this evening over many areas, ending the threat of freezing precipitation. ### Freezing drizzle can produce thin, hard-to-detect layers of ice. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of snow, blowing snow, and strong northwesterly winds is expected this evening. In addition, very large waves, pounding surf, and elevated sea water levels are expected Friday morning. Additional snowfall: near 5 cm this evening. Wave heights: 7 to 9 metres, breaking upon approach to shore Friday morning. Locations: northern Avalon Peninsula. Remarks: Fresh snow and strong winds may cause reduced visibilities in blowing snow over some areas this evening. In addition, a prolonged period of strong winds will cause very large waves to build today and tonight. Storm surge and coastal flooding may occur along shorelines exposed to the north and northeast, especially near the high tide Friday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. Extreme cold is expected tonight and Friday morning with wind chill values colder than minus 55. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Periods of rain or freezing drizzle are expected over Quebec. They will begin early this evening over the Ottawa Valley, the Lower Laurentians, the Greater Montreal and the Montérégie. Precipitation is expected to taper to showers Friday morning or early afternoon over these areas. Freezing precipitation will develop Friday morning over the centre of the province and are expected to persist until late in the day. The Saguenay Area will be affected mainly in the afternoon. Amounts of 2 to 5 millimetres of freezing precipitation are expected locally in these areas. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-27T16:49:23-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 20 to 30 cm is expected. A frontal system pushing across the northern Alaskan Panhandle is spreading significant snow to the Haines Road and South Klondike Highway through today. Total snowfall amounts of 20 to 30 cm are expected. ### Poor weather conditions may contribute to transportation delays. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and visibility frequently near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Blizzard conditions near the Richardson Mountains continue. Falling pressure over the Yukon, combined with higher pressure over the Northwest Territories, is producing strong easterly winds through the Richardson Mountains and generating blizzard conditions. The strong winds are expected to ease this evening. On Saturday morning, a strong low pressure system will arrive from the Gulf of Alaska and combine with the persistent high pressure over the Northwest Territories to again generate blizzard conditions. Blizzard conditions will develop along the Dempster Highway, including near the Richardson and Ogilvie Mountains, beginning early Saturday morning and continuing until late Saturday evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-27T16:43:35-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-27T00:44:35-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2989628223.2019
Area: Dempster
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Additional snowfall: near 5 cm through tonight. Maximum wind gusts: generally northwesterly 70 km/h, except locally 90 km/h along the coast. Time span: continuing until overnight tonight. Locations: Gander and northeastern Newfoundland. Remarks: Strong northwesterly winds with gusts between 70 and 90 km/h will combine with the fresh snowfall to cause reduced visibilities in blowing snow, especially over exposed areas. Conditions will improve overnight as the snow tapers off. ### Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

There maybe be near zero visibility in some areas tonight, especially over higher terrain. Travel may become hazardous tonight due to reduced visibility. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-27T15:07:04-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. Additional snowfall: near 5 cm tonight. Maximum wind gusts: northwesterly 80 km/h. Time span: continuing until overnight tonight. Locations: Clarenville and Terra Nova. Remarks: Strong northwesterly winds gusting between 70 and 80 km/h will combine with the fresh snowfall to cause reduced visibilities in blowing snow, especially over exposed areas. ### Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-27T07:59:40-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-26T19:22:40-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3464195870.2019
Area: Clarenville and vicinity, Terra Nova
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Very large waves, pounding surf, and elevated sea water levels are expected Friday morning. Wave heights: 7 to 9 metres, breaking upon approach to shore. Locations: east and northeast coasts of Newfoundland. Time span: Friday morning. Remarks: A prolonged period of strong winds will cause very large waves to build today. Storm surge and coastal flooding may occur along shorelines exposed to the north and northeast, especially near high tide Friday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-27T11:22:48-00:00

Area: Bay of Exploits, Bonavista North, Bonavista Peninsula, Clarenville and vicinity, Terra Nova
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow, blowing snow and strong winds are expected to continue. Additional snowfall: near 5 cm tonight. Maximum wind gusts: generally northwesterly 80 km/h, except locally 100 km/h along the coast. Time span: continuing until overnight tonight. Locations: Bonavista Peninsula. Remarks: Strong northwesterly winds gusting between 80 and 100 km/h will persist today and will combine with the fresh snowfall to cause reduced visibilities in blowing snow, especially over exposed areas. Conditions will improve overnight as the snow tapers off. ### Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-27T07:59:18-00:00
